metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 611; Corequisites: NURS 632; Repeatable: 5 times; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: The second of three courses focused on preparing students in the Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs).
course_title: Theory: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan II
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Student will conduct a complex service project for a public or community based agency. May be taken for 1-6 credits. (45 hours of practicum experience awarded for each one credit of the course)
course_title: Advanced Practice Population Health Nursing Practicum
metadata: Prerequisites: 24 credits of MS in Advanced Population Health Nursing or consent.; Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Introduces the major fields of philosophy for use in research. Frameworks for the evaluation and critique of philosophical approaches to research will be explored, debated, analyzed, and applied as relevant to the PhD student’s dissertation.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Faculty guided research opportunity to gain mastery of research skills and techniques through participation in mentored research.
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 741 (with a minimum grade of B-), NURS 742 (with a minimum grade of B-), NURS 751 (with a minimum grade of B-) and a quantitative methods course.; Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: PhD students only.

course_desc: The final of three courses focused on preparing students in the Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs).
course_title: Theory: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan III
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Examination of quality of health care, the process of managing health-care outcomes and costs in the delivery of care through the interdisciplinary process.
course_title: Best Practices in Leading Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality
metadata: Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Evaluates the impact of history on the culture of nursing and nursing education. Explore strategies to provide education in a culturally sensitive manner to culturally diverse students.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: graduate standing, or consent.

course_desc: Introduces evidence-based practice methods for improving the quality of nursing practice. Develops skills in differentiating quantitative and qualitative research, statistical methods, and searching, critiquing, and synthesizing literature, pertinent to health care issues.
metadata: Prerequisites: permission of course faculty.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only

course_desc: Analyze biologic, psychosocial, physiologic, and health disparity aspects with conceptual application to healthcare of the aging population. Demonstrate understanding and distinguish normal changes from common disease-related changes.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Development and refinement of the student’s research area of interest. Synthesis of theory from nursing and related disciplines. Articulation of the problem, significance, purpose of inquiry, related question(s), hypotheses (as applicable) and specific aims.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: Nursing majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: PhD students only.

course_desc: Current trends of planning for evaluation and critical analysis and application of curriculum evaluation in nursing curriculum.
course_title: Curriculum Evaluation & Accreditation in Nursing Education
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 747 with a minimum grade of B-.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Overview of scientific approaches relevant to nursing and health care research. Application of quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methods research approaches for answering questions and generating knowledge relevant to the discipline and practice of nursing.
course_title: Research Design and Methods for Nursing Science
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: Nursing majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: PhD students only.

course_desc: Therapeutic modalities used in advanced practice psychiatric-mental health nursing with individuals, families, and groups representing culturally diverse populations.
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 611; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Intermediate level practicum. Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, management, and evaluation of clients in supervised clinical practicum for advanced practice nursing focusing on adults with acute or chronic diagnoses in primary care.
course_title: Primary Care II Lab (intermediate level): Acute & Chronic Conditions (Adult)
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 676 / NURS 676L .; Repeatable: 1 time, up to 5 credits.; Grade Option: CR/NC only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Qualitative methods and approaches to research used in nursing and health sciences will be examined. Multiple paradigms and traditions will be reviewed, including culturally safe approaches and indigenous methodologies.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.

course_desc: Family systems approach to include selected family theories, family research and family centered culturally sensitive clinical assessment and intervention in health and illness situations.
course_title: Family Systems in Health and Illness
metadata: Class Standing Restrictions: graduate standing or consent.

course_desc: Directed study of problems related to nursing theory and practice.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Repeatable: Unlimited times

course_desc: Advanced level clinical experience. Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management of clients across the lifespan in primary care settings for advanced practice nursing students.
course_title: Primary Care IV Lab (advanced level): Primary Care Integration Across the Lifespan
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 678 / NURS 678L .; Grade Option: CR/NC only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: A culminating experience in nursing education and leadership program designed for students to integrate, critique, extend, and apply knowledge gained in the program.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( NURS 732 and NURS 747 ) with a minimum grade of B-.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Exploration of a variety of philosophies of science and examination of factors influencing the development of nursing theory and the emergence of nursing as a discipline.
metadata: Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Integrate scientific findings from various fields of study to the leadership and management of healthcare systems to ensure the delivery of quality and safe care.
course_title: Foundation of Health Systems and Translation Science
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only

course_desc: Exploration of a variety of philosophies of science and examination of factors influencing the development of nursing theory and disciplinary thought.
course_title: Philosophical Thought and Disciplinary Knowledge for Nursing
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: Nursing majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: PhD students only.

course_desc: The role of the advanced professional nurse in public health preparedness, planning and response. Includes 45 hours of field work where the student will practice emergency response functional roles.
course_title: Advanced Practice Nursing During Public Health Disasters
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Summer only; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Nursing research methods for qualitative and quantitative studies, institutional review board procedures, and how to develop a research proposal.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Introduction to medical jurisprudence, medical malpractice, informed consent, health care decisions, medical ethics, the health care industry, managed care, financing health care, and the role of government in health care.
metadata: Major Restrictions: LAW majors only; NURS DNP majors only; Cross-Listed: LAW 532

course_desc: Advanced application of multivariate statistics to analyze complex problems of interest to nursing in culturally diverse populations.
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 741 and NURS 752 or equivalent courses, or consent. Once a year.; Grade Option: A-F only.

course_desc: Advanced level seminar. Students will discuss current evidence, concepts, and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management focusing on primary care of clients across the lifespan.
course_title: Primary Care IV Seminar: Primary Care Integration Across the Lifespan
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 678 / NURS 678L .; Corequisites: NURS 679L .; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Culminating seminar synthesizing and applying concepts from all APRN didactic course work, using case/problem-based learning via student and faculty-guided discussions.
course_title: Diagnosis & Management of Complex Care Across the Lifespan
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Provides a foundation of concepts necessary to maintain and promote women’s health, including developmental, physiological and social needs of women of all ages and the management of common health problems and concerns specific to women.
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 612 / NURS 612L , NURS 613 , and NURS 629 .; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only or consent.

course_desc: Designed to introduce students to grants, grant writing, and grant management. Combined lecture discussion, seminar, and exercises on grants, grant writing, and grant management for health sciences. Open to NURS students only, others with approval.
metadata: Prerequisites: instructor consent.; Repeatable: 1 time; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Seminar to discuss the evidence, concepts, and principles of assessment, diagnosis, management. Utilization of clinical cases and current literature on health care assessment.
course_title: Primary Care I Seminar: Health Assessment
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 612 / NURS 612L , NURS 613 , and NURS 629 .; Corequisites: NURS 676L .; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Supervised experience in executive nursing leadership to address important health issues for high-risk or under-served populations utilizing an interdisciplinary systems-based approach.
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 664 and NURS 774 (or concurrent), or consent.; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.

course_desc: Students advance skills for development and peer critique of research proposals, honing grant and scientific writing skills.  Emphasis placed on dissemination strategies relevant and affirming to culturally diverse/marginalized populations and multidisciplinary professional audiences.
course_title: Seminar IV: Building a Program of Research
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: Nursing majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: PhD students only.

course_desc: Using knowledge of translational science, designs an implementation plan for a practice guideline. Determines evaluation methods and selects outcome variables that best measure success. Discusses institutionalization of, and identifies facilitators and barriers to, practice change.
course_title: Implementation and Evaluation Strategies for Evidence-Based Practice
metadata: Prerequisites: NURS 669; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Major Restrictions: NURS majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate standing only.

course_desc: Year-long clerkship in outpatient setting, covering assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and/ or management of common gynecologic problems and normal and complicated pregnancies. Emphasis on prevention and health maintenance.
metadata: Prerequisites: third-year standing, and concurrent registration in OBGN 532 courses.; Corequisites: FMCH, MED, PED, PSTY, and SURG 632.; Repeatable: 2 times

course_desc: Major design experience based on knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work and incorporating realistic constraints that include economic, environmental, ethical, social, and liability considerations. Emphasis is placed on teamwork and consultant-client relationship. (B) coastal engineering; (C) offshore engineering; (D) ocean resources engineering; (E) oceanic engineering.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( ORE 411 , ORE 603 , and ORE 607 ) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only for (E); Major Restrictions: ORE majors only.

course_desc: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment.
course_title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 102 (or concurrent) or GES 102 or (or concurrent) SUST 112 (or concurrent).; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: GES 102L and SUST 112L; General Education Designation(s): DY

course_desc: Introduction to modeling biogeochemical and physical oceanic processes by building a coupled model of the Pacific to investigate physical effects on plankton blooms. Students learn ecosystem dynamics, basic numerical methods, and programming.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( OCN 310 / ATMO 310 or GES 311 or PHYS 272 , and OCN 312 / ERTH 312 ) with a minimum grade of B-.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Major Restrictions: GES majors only.

course_desc: Marine functional genomics, biodiversity of marine natural habitats, marine microbial communities and their ecological functions, interactions of marine microbes and their host, climate change and marine biodiversity, marine biotechnology.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 or MICR 130 , or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Cross-Listed: MBBE 405

course_desc: Introduction to pre-calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science. Students work on real-world problems and engage in participatory learning. Preparatory for classes in calculus and physics.
course_title: Introduction to Quantitative Earth and Environmental Science
metadata: Prerequisites: MATH 134 , MATH 161 , or MATH assessment exam (with score required for MATH 140X ).; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Cross-Listed: ATMO 150

course_desc: Origin and features of ocean basins and seawater; global cycles of carbon and nutrients; currents; waves; tides; characteristics of marine organisms; marine ecological principles; marine pollution; climate change causes and consequences. Online asynchronous; synchronous format.
metadata: General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Required for entering SOEST majors to develop skills and applications for a successful college experience. Students will examine academic goals and implement strategies to achieve goals including time management and career exploration.
metadata: Grade Option: CR/NC only.; Major Restrictions: SOEST majors only.

course_desc: Advanced mathematical methods with emphasis on application to the earth and ocean sciences and engineering. Topics include linear algebra, vector calculus, ordinary differential equations, and numerical methods.
course_title: Advanced Mathematics for Scientists and Engineers I
metadata: Prerequisites: MATH 242 or consent.; Cross-Listed: ERTH 312

course_desc: The following topics will be addressed: How are cities impacted by, and impacting climate change? How do urbanization, alteration of atmospheric processes, and extreme weather events affect urban systems and populations?
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 363 or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only

course_desc: Major design experience based on knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work and incorporating realistic constraints that include economic, environmental, ethical, social, and liability considerations. Emphasis is placed on teamwork and consultant-client relationship. (B) coastal engineering; (C) offshore engineering; (D) ocean resources engineering; (E) oceanic engineering.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( ORE 411 , ORE 603 , and ORE 607 ) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only for (E); Major Restrictions: ORE majors only.

course_desc: Content will reflect special interests of visiting and permanent faculty.
course_title: Special Topics in Ocean and Resources Engineering
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Repeatable: Unlimited times

course_desc: Attendance at 15 approved seminars is required along with submission of notes.
course_title: Seminar in Ocean and Resources Engineering

course_desc: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed.
metadata: Prerequisites: master’s candidacy in ORE.

course_desc: Experiments, computer exercises, and field trips demonstrating the geological, physical, chemical, and biological principles of earth and ocean sciences.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 (or concurrent).; Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DY

course_desc: Introductory experience in energy systems including current status of fossil fuel, renewable energy technologies, energy utilization and conservation; environmental and policy aspects.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only

course_desc: Covers principles of remote sensing technologies for land, ocean, and climate applications. Students will explore the fundamentals of electromagnetic radiation, and learn to critically interpret patterns in environmental changes over time and space.
metadata: Prerequisites: MATH 242 and PHYS 170 .; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only.

course_desc: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Class Standing Restrictions: Junior standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: CEE 441 and SUST 441

course_desc: Activities in marine minerals development are examined in a multidisciplinary systems approach involving engineering, Earth and environmental sciences and economics.
metadata: Class Standing Restrictions: graduate standing or consent.

course_desc: Directed research in which the student carries out a scientific project of small to moderate scope with one or more chosen advisors. The student must complete a document in the style of a scientific journal article.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Repeatable: Up to 6 credit hours.; Cross-Listed: GES 499

course_desc: Watershed and coastal biogeochemistry/ecosystem science. Emphasis on field surveying and sampling of stream and reef habitats; laboratory chemical/biological analyses. Analysis of land use impacts on ecosystem health and ahupuaʻa resource management.
course_title: Ridge to Reef: Coastal Ecosystem Ecology and Connectivity
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 / OCN 201L ; and either OCN 310 / ATMO 310 , or GES 311 ; or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.

course_desc: Survey of human activities in the ocean, from the most traditional to the most innovative technical and engineering accomplishments.
metadata: General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Hydrodynamics of ships, coastal and offshore structures. Wave forces by potential theory and by Morison’s equation. Method of source distribution for potential flow problems. Flows with prescribed body motion, fixed and freely floating bodies.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 607 or consent.

course_desc: Opportunities for advanced study of selected topics. (B) labor and delivery; (D) sub-internship in family planning; (E) high-risk OB; (F) endocrinology; (G) oncology; (H) topics with individual preceptor; (I) extramural electives.
metadata: Prerequisites: OBGN 531 or OBGN 532 .; Repeatable: 2 times for each alpha.; Grade Option: CR/NC only.

course_desc: Introduction to environmental monitoring systems for earth science students. Students will learn how to construct, program, and deploy simple environmental monitoring systems to collect in-situ environmental data.
course_title: Introduction to Environmental Monitoring Systems and Measurements
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 / OCN 201L or ERTH 101 / ERTH 101L , CHEM 161 / CHEM 161L , and MATH 241 ; or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Major Restrictions: OCN, ERTH, ATMO majors only.

course_desc: Practical laboratory dedicated to wave science covering generation, propagation, transformation, and coastal processes related to surfing and the ocean environment through technology.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DY

course_desc: Sediment transport by waves and currents in coastal areas and its effect on morphological processes. Effect of man-made structures on littoral drift and shoreline.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 607 or consent.

course_desc: Opportunities for advanced study of selected topics. (B) labor and delivery; (D) sub-internship in family planning; (E) high-risk OB; (F) endocrinology; (G) oncology; (H) topics with individual preceptor; (I) extramural electives.
course_title: Electives in OB/GYN: labor and delivery
metadata: Prerequisites: OBGN 531 or OBGN 532 .; Repeatable: 2 times for each alpha.; Grade Option: CR/NC only.

course_desc: Sediments, structure, geophysics, geochemistry, history of ocean basins and margins.
metadata: Prerequisites: ERTH 200 and ERTH 302 , or consent.; Cross-Listed: ERTH 423; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Introduction to the environment, climate change, and sustainability as they apply to ecosystems. Sustainability will be introduced through active learning exercises that address sustainable development and the three pillars of sustainability.
course_title: Introduction to the Environment, Climate Change, & Sustainability
metadata: Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: GES 102 and SUST 112; General Education Designation(s): DB

course_desc: Introduction to the principles of sustainability analysis through execution of Life Cycle Analysis applied to products, processes, or systems. LCA and the evaluation of environmental impact will be presented. Personal computer or laptop (Word 97 or higher) OS, and minimum of 4GB RAM.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( CHEM 161 and PHYS 170 ) with a minimum grade of C-; Junior standing or higher, or consent.; Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only

course_desc: Relationship of biogeochemical cycles in the atmosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere to global chemical cycles and planetary climatic conditions. GES degree foundation and capstone course with an emphasis on improving student writing skills.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 , GES 311 , BIOL 172 / BIOL 172L , CHEM 162 / CHEM 162L , ERTH 101 / ERTH 101L , GES 319L (or concurrent), ATMO 200 (or concurrent), and GES 499 / OCN 499 (or concurrent); or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Major Restrictions: GES majors only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Senior standing only.; Cross-Listed: GES 401; General Education Designation(s): DP
Repeatable: Unlimited times; Major Restrictions: candidacy for PhD in ocean and resources engineering.

course_desc: Combined lecture and discussion examining biological and physical interactions in the oceans and their impacts on the functioning of marine ecosystems.
course_title: Dynamics of Marine Ecosystems: Biological-Physical Interactions in the Oceans
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 / OCN 201L , GES 311 , GES 319L , and PHYS 272 / PHYS 272L ; and consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Alt years; Major Restrictions: GES majors only.

course_desc: Theory and practice of aquaculture: reproduction, yield trials, management, economics, and business case studies of fish, crustaceans, and molluscs. Field classes held at commercial farm and hatchery.
metadata: Prerequisites: ANSC 321 and ANSC 445 : or BIOL 172 / BIOL 172L and CHEM 162 / CHEM 162L or higher.; Cross-Listed: ANSC 450; General Education Designation(s): DB

course_desc: Student carries out a scientific project of small to moderate scope with one or more chosen advisors. Student must complete a document in the style of a scientific journal article.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Repeatable: up to six (6) credits.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.

course_desc: Structural and finite element analyses and design of ocean structures to withstand hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loading of the sea. Considerations include material type, safety factor, stress concentration, and fatigue.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Corequisites: ORE 411

course_desc: Reading and research in any area of Oceanography under the direction of a faculty member.
metadata: Repeatable: Up to 6 credits.

course_desc: Combined lecture, discussion, and laboratory on global Earth system databases and satellite instrumentation, including computer laboratory.
metadata: Prerequisites: MATH 242 ; or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: GES majors only.; Cross-Listed: GES 463; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Lecture/discussion to provide instruction and experience in oral and written presentation of scientific results and material.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 499 / GES 499 (or concurrent).; Grade Option: A-F only.; Major Restrictions: GES majors only in their final semester.; Cross-Listed: GES 490

course_desc: Lecture/discussion introduces students to the field of biology through the integration of microbiology and macrobiology into a single, comprehensive systems biology with a focus on Hawaiian biomes and ecosystem sustainability.
course_title: An Introduction to Integrative Systems Biology: Hawaiian Biomes as a Framework
metadata: Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Cross-Listed: SUST 103; General Education Designation(s): DB

course_desc: Specialized Earth Science topics workshops designed for in-service teachers who wish to learn new approaches and content areas in geology and geophysics, meteorology and oceanography. Credits earned cannot be applied for graduate degrees.
metadata: Repeatable: Up to 12 credits.

course_desc: Introduction to wave science covering generation, propagation, transformation, and coastal processes related to surfing and the human interaction with the ocean using multiple perspectives.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Governing equations in free surface flow, deterministic and probabilistic wave theories, wave transformation, wave-induced coastal currents, tides, ocean engineering operational sea state, and design wave criteria.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.

course_desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Quantitative geometrical analysis techniques of plate tectonics theory; instantaneous and finite rotation poles; triple-junction analysis; plate boundary stresses.
metadata: Prerequisites: ERTH 200 or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Alt years; Cross-Listed: ERTH 444; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Lecture on the diversity and function of the Earth’s microbiomes, inclusive of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, symbiotic and free living microorganisms with a focus on the microbial underpinnings of the Earth’s biogeochemistry.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 or BOT 305 / BIOL 305 or BOT 201 or BIOL 275 or MICR 351 or consent.; Repeatable: Unlimited times.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only.; Cross-Listed: GES 454; General Education Designation(s): DB

course_desc: (1.5 Lec, 1.5 Discussion) Biology and ecology of deep-sea organisms and communities. Topics including benthopelagic coupling, depth zonation, energetics, diversity, adaptations, hydrothermal vents, seamounts, abyssal plains, deep-sea resource extraction and global climate change.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 and BIOL 265 , or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Alt years

course_desc: Ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC) systems: applicability, thermodynamics, design challenges; wave energy converters: floating devices, oscillating water column, optimal hydrodynamic performance; current, tidal, and offshore wind power.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 607 ; basic knowledge of thermodynamics desirable.; Cross-Listed: SUST 677

course_desc: Seminar to introduce new GES majors to the research interests of GES faculty and the research facilities available within SOEST.
metadata: Grade Option: CR/ NC only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Major Restrictions: GES majors.; Cross-Listed: GES 100

course_desc: Using sound to observe the ocean. Fundamentals of propagation. Topics include marine mammals, navigation and communication, seismics, ships, wind and rain, ocean dynamics, flow and biological imaging and measurement, seafloor mapping, and the forward/inverse problem.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Once a year

course_desc: Hard mineral and petroleum origins, exploration and exploitation. Renewable and non-renewable resources distribution. Political and scientific constraints.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 202 or OCN 201 , or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: OCN 330; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Planning and design of seawalls, groins, jetties, breakwaters, and layout of ports. Design requirements for harbor entrances and channels. Littoral drift and sedimentation problems. Navigation and mooring requirements.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 607 or consent.
Prerequisites: consent.

course_desc: Higher-order theories. Forced oscillations. Stoke’s theory. Nonlinear shallow-water wave equations and hydraulic jumps; effects of rotation. Internal waves. Analytical techniques necessary will be developed as course progresses.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 607 with a B- grade.

course_desc: Focus on understanding the changing ocean conditions (e.g. waves and sea levels) relevant to the resilience of practical ocean engineering applications.
course_title: Ocean Engineering and Resilience in a Changing Climate
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 607 or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate students only.

course_desc: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015.
metadata: Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Class Standing Restrictions: Junior standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: SUST 442 and TIM 462

course_desc: Coastal modeling using the SMS Surface-Water Modeling software. Applications to solving coastal problems for different ocean hazard scenarios by applying models for tides, waves, coastal circulation, wave-current interaction, sediment transport, and/or morphology change.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent; knowledge of ORE 607 desirable.; Cross-Listed: CEE 624 and SUST 624

course_desc: Opportunities for advanced study of selected topics. (B) labor and delivery; (D) sub-internship in family planning; (E) high-risk OB; (F) endocrinology; (G) oncology; (H) topics with individual preceptor; (I) extramural electives.
course_title: Electives in OB/GYN: topics with individual preceptor
metadata: Prerequisites: OBGN 531 or OBGN 532 .; Repeatable: 2 times for each alpha.; Grade Option: CR/NC only.

course_desc: Major design experience based on knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work and incorporating realistic constraints that include economic, environmental, ethical, social, and liability considerations. Emphasis is placed on teamwork and consultant-client relationship. (B) coastal engineering; (C) offshore engineering; (D) ocean resources engineering; (E) oceanic engineering.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( ORE 411 , ORE 603 , and ORE 607 ) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only for (E); Major Restrictions: ORE majors only.

course_desc: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable.; Cross-Listed: CEE 621 and SUST 621

course_desc: Fluid dynamics for coastal and estuarine environments. Turbulent mixing processes in homogeneous and stratified fluids. Buoyancy driven flows, internal hydraulics, topographic effects and estuarine circulation. Spill and pollutant dispersal.
metadata: Prerequisites: ORE 603 or consent.

course_desc: Hard mineral and petroleum origins, exploration, and exploitation. Renewable and non-renewable resources distribution. Political and scientific constraints.
course_title: Mineral and Energy Resources of the Sea
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 , ORE 202 ; or consent.; Cross-Listed: ORE 330; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Major design experience based on knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work and incorporating realistic constraints that include economic, environmental, ethical, social, and liability considerations. Emphasis is placed on teamwork and consultant-client relationship. (B) coastal engineering; (C) offshore engineering; (D) ocean resources engineering; (E) oceanic engineering.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( ORE 411 , ORE 603 , and ORE 607 ) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only for (E); Major Restrictions: ORE majors only.

course_desc: Directed reading in earth system science, oceanography, or environmental science.
metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Repeatable: Up to 6 credits.; Cross-Listed: GES 399

course_desc: Pollution of freshwater and marine systems by human activities. Causes, consequences, and correctives. This course develops written communication skills.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 201 , CHEM 161 , BIOL 171 .; Cross-Listed: GES 320; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Experiential approach to earth science; students serve as interns to field professionals; responsibilities include supervised field work.

course_desc: Opportunities for advanced study of selected topics. (B) labor and delivery; (D) sub-internship in family planning; (E) high-risk OB; (F) endocrinology; (G) oncology; (H) topics with individual preceptor; (I) extramural electives.

course_title: Re/Presenting Oceania: Pacific and American Perspectives

course_desc: Overview of how oceanographic processes influence the distribution, life history, and abundance of fishery-relevant species. Topics will largely center on applications to Hawaiʻi, tropical/sub-tropical ecosystems, and the broader Pacific.
course_title: Fisheries Oceanography: From Physics to Landings
metadata: Prerequisites: C or better in OCN 620 or OCN 621 , and a background in biological oceanography and/or physical oceanography required.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only.

course_desc: Survey of contemporary conflict management and resolution: negotiation, mediation, conciliation, ombuds, fact-finding, facilitation techniques, arbitration, and litigation.
metadata: Prerequisites: any social science 100- or 200-level course or consent.; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Introduction to the organization and functioning of oceanography funding agencies, the peer-review process, and the design and development of a research proposal.
metadata: Prerequisites: two of the following: OCN 621 , OCN 626 , OCN 627 (or concurrent), or OCN 628 (or concurrent); or consent.; Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: CR/NC only.; Major Restrictions: OCN majors only.

course_desc: Individualized instruction in laboratory medicine for the practicing physician, clinical and anatomic pathology: (B) advanced topics in clinical immunology; (C) anatomic pathology; (D) clinical pathology; (E) pathologic aspects of aging, nutrition, and/or alcoholism; (F) extramural elective in pathology.
course_title: Unit VII Electives in Pathology: anatomic pathology
metadata: Prerequisites: BIOM 555.; Repeatable: 4 times; Grade Option: CR/NC only.

course_desc: Reading and research on major issues, topics, and themes in the history of Oceania.
metadata: Repeatable: 3 times.; Class Standing Restrictions: graduate standing or consent.; Cross-Listed: HIST 675

course_desc: Applies an island studies perspective to critically evaluate the commonalities and differences across islands and archipelagos in several world regions. Examines how island geographies influence social identities and movements and are impacted by environmental conditions.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: GEO 333; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Exploration of scientific and cultural resources for nonviolent alternatives in politics.

course_desc: Application of the scientific method; physical regimes in the ocean; ocean processes and observational strategies; resolution, sampling, array design and observing systems; models and data assimilation; major field programs; operational oceanography and climate prediction.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 620 and consent.

course_desc: Introduction to classical hydrodynamics and continuum mechanics. Techniques for solution of Navier Stokes equations on various scales of oceanic motion; potential theory, dynamic modeling, and viscous and rotational processes.
metadata: Prerequisites: MATH 403 .

course_desc: Thermodynamics of stratified fluids; convection; mixing; models of the thermohaline circulation; the role of eddies in the large-scale ocean circulation.
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 667 or consent.

course_desc: Required elective for second-year medical students, objectives to be determined by contract. One option is a review of USMLE Part I.

metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Major Restrictions: Open to nonmajors.

course_desc: Introduction to the problems individuals and political communities currently face with respect to war, peace, and international conflict. Includes questions of human nature, economy, morality, nuclear deterrence, arms control and disarmament, and alternatives to war.
metadata: Cross-Listed: POLS 201; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Explores the characteristics of organizations from different perspectives including structural, political, ethical, and cultural frames from organizational theory and practice. Focuses on how to design organizational change strategies and facilitate their implementation.

course_desc: Interactive seminar series to cover the following topics: data types, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, selecting a statistical test, data distributions, measures of data spread, statistical test assumptions, standard deviation vs. standard error, etc.

course_desc: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global.

course_desc: Advanced practice course for students specializing in social work with children and families. Designed to provide students with an in-depth understanding of both theoretical formulations and therapeutic techniques for practice in the field of family and child welfare. Emphasis placed on the development of specialized knowledge and skills for assessment, intervention, and evaluation of a variety of common child and family practice situations.

course_desc: Study of the dominant trend of economic change and its impact on society; globalization of economic activities and transformation of industrial society to postindustrial one; corporate restructuring and downsizing and their impact on employment and income distribution; gender relations in workplaces; the impact of globalization on the newly industrializing countries.
metadata: Prerequisites: SOC 300 or consent.; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Designed for students in the child and family concentration and builds upon past knowledge and skill development in practice classes and in the practicum. Meets seminar requirement.

metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DS Honors Program restriction: Yes

course_desc: Examines the problem of violence, particularly sexual violence, over the life cycle. Offers gendered perspective in activities aimed at prevention and treatment of violence, and cross cultural perspectives.

metadata: General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Relationships between law, politics, and society will be explored. Emphasis is placed on several dimensions of legality: legal “indeterminacy” and some of the many things that law does for us and to us; law’s response to violence; the connections between law and social change; access to the law and its sociological dimensions; how/why law fails and what happens when it does.
metadata: Prerequisites: SOC 100 or any 200 level SOC course, or a 100 level or 200 level POLS course, or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: POLS 374; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Prisons, jails, and other detention facilities across historical, social, and/or international contexts.

course_desc: Didactic and experiential learning activity focuses on the major role functions of the social worker in the health field including assessment, contracting, counseling, advocacy, case management, discharge planning, family group work, community and team building. course_desc: Interrelations of deviance, criminology, juvenile delinquency, corrections, social control, sociology of law. Key concepts, theories.

course_desc: Multivariate forms of multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, and analysis of co-variance. Multiple discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, and principal components analysis are discussed.

course_desc: Foundations of “special education” exploring philosophies, diverse and historical viewpoints, laws, and service delivery. Students reflect upon texts, films and interviews with persons with disabilities, their families and professionals to understand the culture of disability.

course_desc: Principles and laws governing human behavior and positive methods for eliminating significant behavior problems for students with severe disabilities and autism. Emphasis on the functions of behavior, experimental techniques for documenting behavior change, and the use of technologies for improving behavior in school and community settings.

metadata: Prerequisites: consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.

metadata: Prerequisites: one of SPED 480, LTEC 414 , or LTEC 442 .

metadata: Prerequisites: admission into Deaf Education program or consent.; Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Alt years

Appropriate for special/general education teachers, administrators, or related service providers.

course_desc: Provide a scientific basis to examine the consequences of climate change and the proposed geoengineering solutions, and examine the fundamental ethical basis that underlies environmental policies.
course_title: The Ethics of Climate Change and Geoengineering
metadata: Prerequisites: OCN 310 .; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Alt. years: spring; Cross-Listed: OCN 411

course_desc: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. Senior standing or higher, or consent.
course_title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis and Applications
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: ATMO 449 and CEE 449

course_desc: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Cross-Listed: CEE 441 and OCN 441

course_desc: Biological and physical science aspects of natural resource management at local, national, and global scales. Topics covered include resource management of soil, water, forests, wetlands, coasts and wildlife.
metadata: Prerequisites: ( NREM 251 / TPSS 251 or NREM 210 / TPSS 210 ; CHEM 151 or higher; and BIOL 172 ) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Cross-Listed: NREM 301; General Education Designation(s): DB

course_desc: Human interaction with the environment. How market, property institution, and technological change affect the environment. Epistemological basis of environmental policies. Debates on controversial environmental issues.
metadata: Prerequisites: SUST 102 , SUST 151, or consent.; Cross-Listed: GEO 426; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Examines some perspectives on Ecology within the context of Indigenous and Local Knowledge systems, and some approaches to conservation by Indigenous Peoples and Local Communities.
metadata: Prerequisites: BIOL 265 or BIOL 301 or BIOL 305 / BOT 305 or consent.; Cross-Listed: BOT 444; General Education Designation(s): DB

course_desc: Examines resilience thinking as it relates to making cities resilient to environmental hazards in the context of climate change. Draws on relevant theories, policy, and case studies in urban planning. Emphasis on instruction in writing.
metadata: Class Standing Restrictions: Junior standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: PLAN 414

course_desc: Explores the related concepts of use, re-use, and radical re-use through an exploration of new applications of traditional fiber techniques and contexts of making. Engages writing as a significant tool for art-making and analysis.
metadata: Prerequisites: ART 116 or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: ART 436; General Education Designation(s): DA

course_desc: Theory and tools for working with groups and communities in the management of natural resources is presented using a participatory format. Topics include sustainable development, extension programming, participatory learning and communication, evaluation, and conflict management.
metadata: Prerequisites: two social science courses (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Cross-Listed: NREM 420; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Introduction to the environmental humanities, which rests at the intersection of the arts, humanities, and environmental studies.
metadata: Cross-Listed: IS 260; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Hawaiʻi’s economic transformation from sustainable communal subsistence through mercantile capitalism, plantation capitalism, and global finance capital and impact on its people. Alternative sustainable enterprises for a self-sufficient island economy.
metadata: Prerequisites: one DS or DH course.; Cross-Listed: ES 350; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Conceptual schemes and processes for integrating science curricula within the sciences and with subject areas. Methods and models of curricular integration such as interdisciplinary, culturally relevant, place and community-based learning.
metadata: Repeatable: 1 time; Cross-Listed: EDCS 433
Class Standing Restrictions: Junior standing or higher, or consent.; Cross-Listed: PLAN 310; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Theory and applications of contaminant/pollutant distribution in the hydrosphere-geosphere-biosphere-atmosphere system, remediation methods, prevention, industrial/ agricultural best practices. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, organic, inorganic, gas phase, and ecosystem impacts of environmental contaminants.
metadata: Prerequisites: CHEM 161 and CHEM 162 , or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Cross-Listed: ERTH 425; General Education Designation(s): DP

course_desc: Introduces fundamental techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management.
metadata: Prerequisites: BIOL 171 .; Repeatable: 1 time; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Cross-Listed: NREM 410

course_desc: Introduction to natural resource and environmental public policy at U.S. federal, Hawaiʻi state, local, and international levels. Policy principles, legal structure, governmental agencies, statutes and programs, analytical techniques, program assessments, and contemporary ethical issues.
metadata: Prerequisites: NREM 210 / PEPS 210 / SUST 210 or NREM 251 / SOCS 251 / TPSS 251 or ( BIOL 101 or higher) or GEO 101 or ( ERTH 101 or higher); and NREM 220 / SUST 220 or one ECON course or two DS courses.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: NREM 302; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Introduction to the methods and techniques of environmental and energy policy in relation to energy systems. Analysis of enacted policies from case studies to understanding the effectiveness, challenges, contradictions, and limitations of each.
course_title: Applied Principles of Environmental & Energy Policy
metadata: Prerequisites: any 100 or 200 level OCN course, or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Class Standing Restrictions: Junior standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: OCN 321 and PPC 340; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Methods and techniques of handling and identifying plant materials used by early Hawaiians and modern Hawaiians for house and canoe construction, clothing, household and fishing items, medicine, and food preparation. Reading, laboratory, and fieldwork.
metadata: Prerequisites: BOT 440 or consent.; Cross-Listed: BOT 446; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Relationship of humans with natural environment; role of culture in ecological systems.
metadata: Prerequisites: 152; Cross-Listed: ANTH 335; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: How do we plan cities to meet long-term social, economic, and environmental needs? Students will learn about sustainability as it relates to issues like energy, transportation, housing, land, water, and food. Emphasis on writing instruction.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: PLAN 101

course_desc: Lecture-based overview of the history, ecology, and management of wildlife species from around the world and Hawaiʻi.
metadata: Prerequisites: BIOL 172 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; Cross-Listed: NREM 450

course_desc: Examination of air quality problems from scientific and policy perspectives. Includes case studies that explore economic, political, technical, and legla aspects of pollution control.
metadata: Class Standing Restrictions: junior standing or higher, or consent.; Cross-Listed: GEO 404

course_desc: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society.

course_desc: The social system, land stewardship, and governance of Native Hawaiians in a Pacific context. Transformation of the Hawaiian system by a capitalist economy. Native Hawaiian regeneration and quest for sovereign governance as an Oceanic society.
metadata: Cross-Listed: ES 221; General Education Designation(s): DS

metadata: Cross-Listed: GEO 322; General Education Designation(s): DS

metadata: Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only; Cross-Listed: CEE 440

course_desc: Analysis of our environment with emphasis on understanding relationships and interactions of physical, biological, technological, and political components using scientific methods of inquiry. Processing of a variety of tropical horticultural plants are presented, with tasting sessions and optional field trips. Topics will rotate among (B) beverage crops (e.g., coffee, tea, chocolate, kava, fruit juices); (C) herbs, spices, and flavoring (selection of examples to be determined); (D) tropical fruits (assortment offered depends on availability during semester); (E) ornamental plants (flowers, houseplants, popular landscape plans, bonsai, ethnic ornamentals). Does not count towards TPSS major.

course_desc: The origins: social, cultural, and ceremonial traditions; culture; food and nutritional properties. course_desc: Explores the impact of the African Diaspora on the cultures and histories of the Americas through interdisciplinary and feminist scholarship and cultural sources including fiction, foodways, film, poetry, religion, music, and dance.
course_title: Gender and the African Diaspora in the Americas
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only. Graduate standing only.; Cross-Listed: AMST 616

course_desc: Exploration of landmark U.S. Supreme Court cases related to sex and gender. Topics may include sex discrimination, sexual orientation discrimination, privacy, and reproductive freedom.
metadata: Prerequisites: one of WGSS 151 , WGSS 175 , WGSS 176 , WGSS 202 , WGSS 360 , WGSS 381 , or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: AMST 436 and POLS 368; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Construction of gender identities in contemporary Asia. How these interface with other aspects of social difference and inequality (e.g. with class, religion, ethnicity).
metadata: Cross-Listed: ASAN 463; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Adaptive strategies of Hawaiian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Samoan, and Southeast Asian women in Hawaiʻi; feminist anthropological and historical analysis.
metadata: Prerequisites: any ANTH, SOC, or WGSS course.; Cross-Listed: ES 365; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Social and economic policies affecting women in families, education, social services, government, health care, the economy; public policy implementation and development; policy impact on women.
metadata: Prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course; or consent.; Cross-Listed: SOC 318; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Using South Korean popular culture as a case study, this lecture/discussion/seminar examines the relationship between popular culture and a range of forces including: politics, international relations, military, social movements, fandoms, and industries.
course_title: Gender, Sexuality, and the Geopolitics of Korean Popular Culture
metadata: Repeatable: Repeatable one time.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Spring only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Junior standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: AMST 412 and ASAN 412 General Education Designation(s):DH ; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Focus on various aspects of Trans* identities, biographies, cultural productions, and communities. It also addresses issues on racism, medical intervention, dating, societal condemnation, mental health, and incarceration. Junior standing or higher.
metadata: Cross-Listed: AMST 437; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Advanced graduate seminar on the key ideas within queer theory. Students will become familiar with theories of queer relationality, queer of color critique, globalization of sexuality, disability and transgender studies, and queer indigeneities.
metadata: Prerequisites: undergraduate or graduate course work in women’s, gender, sexuality, or LGBTQ studies.

course_desc: The military as it includes and excludes women as soldiers, nurses, wives, prostitutes, and victims. Women and war economics; feminism, war, and peace.
metadata: Prerequisites: one of WGSS 151 , WGSS 362 , WGSS 375 or SOC 362 ; or consent.; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Examines the cultural, historical, and political processes that have informed our understandings and practices involving food. We will analyze food and foodways in the U.S. and Hawaiʻi. Junior standing or higher.

metadata: Prerequisites: at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: AMST 448 and ES 450; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Oceania-centric perspective. Analysis of imperialism, colonialism, gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, and queer(ed) relations and identities in Hawaiʻi and the Pacific. Junior standing or higher.

metadata: Prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent.; Cross-Listed: ES 391; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Problems and issues for reading and research: feminist theory, criticism, affirmative action, etc.
metadata: Prerequisites: any WGSS course in appropriate area.; Repeatable: 2 times; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Investigates gender representation in the evolving genre of American action cinema through combined stylistic and cultural analysis, with special attention to the relationship of gendered action to categories of morality, race, class, and nation. Junior standing or consent.
metadata: Cross-Listed: AMST 446; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Examination of basic feminist issues in philosophy, and of responses to them.
metadata: Prerequisites: any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent.; Cross-Listed: PHIL 418; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Explores how gender, sex, and sexuality become key elements in human society from prehistory to 1500 CE. Examines ancient world civilizations from multiple perspectives stressing issues and forces still influential today.

metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Fall only; General Education Designation(s): FGA

course_desc: Seminar/discussion to introduce students pursuing the Graduate Certificate to the Women’s Studies faculty and their areas of research, and to initiate student’s graduate studies in a women’s studies field.
metadata: Repeatable: Repeatable one time.; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate students only.

course_desc: Women’s relations with the criminal justice system; types of women’s offenses; responses to women’s crime; women as victims; women as workers in the criminal justice system. Recommended: at least one WGSS course.
metadata: Prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course, or SOC 300 ; or consent.; Cross-Listed: SOC 435; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Study of authors, a genre, a period, or a problem. (M) modern; (T) traditional.
metadata: Prerequisites: WGSS 613 , WGSS 615 , WGSS 650 , or EALL 611 ; or consent for (M); CHN 612 or consent for (T).; Repeatable: 1 time for (M).; Grade Option: A-F only for (M).; Cross-Listed: CHN 753

course_desc: Relationship between feminist and other sites of critical insight and scholarship that have contributed to creating anticolonial, antiracist, antihomophobic theory, method and action. Questions the legacy of feminist coalition practices and engages the ongoing transformations that have begun to produce new alliances and coalitions that disrupt traditional boundaries of identity and power.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate students only.

course_desc: Provide women’s studies graduate certificate students with an opportunity to design, develop and complete a research project culminating in a publishable quality work and a professional quality seminar presentation.

metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate students only.

course_desc: Legendary priestesses and prophetesses from ancient to modern religions around the world including ancient Sumeria, Egypt, Greece, China, India, the Middle East, Japan, and Hawaiʻi. This course develops written communication skills.
metadata: Frequency of Course (when offered): Summer only.; Cross-Listed: REL 216; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Explores ethics of the present and historic expansions of the fashion industry and its environmental impact globally. Examines how gender/race/class shape garment production and consumption and fashion activism in world regions. Emphasis on oral/written communication.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only. Junior standing or higher.; Cross-Listed: GEO 433; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Interdisciplinary critical examination of the relationship between gender and mental health. Psychological research, feminist theory, autobiography, literature, and cinema.

course_desc: Historical and contemporary experiences of South Asian migrants in North America, Pacific, Caribbean, and/or African diasporas; causes and patterns of migration, inter-ethnic relations policies; role of race, gender, culture in community, identity formation.
course_title: South Asian Migrants: Culture and Politics
metadata: Prerequisites: one ES or WGSS course in the 100, 200 or 300 level; or consent.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Frequency of Course (when offered): Once a year; Cross-Listed: ES 339; General Education Designation(s): DS

metadata: Prerequisites: ENG 100 , ENG 100A , or ESL 100 .; General Education Designation(s): DL

course_desc: Laboratory to accompany
metadata: Prerequisites: ZOOL 101 (or concurrent).; General Education Designation(s): DY

metadata: Prerequisites: WGSS 151 or PSY 100 .; Grade Option: A-F only.; Cross-Listed: PSY 202; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: A survey and critical examination of contemporary Chinese women writers from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Traces a genealogy of women’s writing from the early 1920s up until now through novels, poetry, drama, and film.
metadata: Prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent.; Cross-Listed: ASAN 364 and EALL 364; General Education Designation(s): DL

course_desc: Students learn theories of the global economy, histories of consumerism, constructions of gendered public spaces, and how the cultural production of consumers and consumer culture functions in the process of globalization.

metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories.
metadata: Prerequisites: Consent of instructor.; Repeatable: 2 times, up to 12 credits.; Cross-Listed: SOC 494 and SOCS 489

course_desc: Twentieth-century women writers and their works; novels, short stories, poems, autobiographies. Interrelations of gender and literature.
metadata: Prerequisites: (one of WGSS 151 , WGSS 175 , WGSS 176 ), and WGSS 245 ; or consent.; General Education Designation(s): DL

course_desc: Introduction to a survey of the key terms, texts, and histories of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities with special attention to Hawaiʻi and Oceania.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: History of U.S. women and gender relations. Topics include women’s work, women in social movements, changing norms regarding gender and sexuality, and shared and divergent experiences of women. Emphasis on ethical issues.
metadata: Cross-Listed: AMST 316 and HIST 361; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: Examines the origins and futures of Indigenous feminist theory and praxis. Topics explored include cultural revitalization, colonialism, and sexual violence in Indigenous communities, citizenship and sovereignty, and contemporary Native gender roles and identity.
metadata: Prerequisites: WGSS 151 or consent.; General Education Designation(s): DH

course_desc: History, culture, and contemporary reality of Asian women in Asia and the U.S. Includes critical analysis of American feminist methodology and theory.

course_desc: Status of women in American society today in light of the cultural, historical, and philosophical forces that have produced it.

course_desc: Survey of major critical works in fields of performing arts and public culture (e.g., dance, theater, music, commemoration). Topics include: theoretical application for the discipline of American studies, and the impact of social movements and labor migration on the performing arts.
metadata: Cross-Listed: AMST 615

course_desc: Explores the influence of gender in sport from cultural, psychosocial, and political perspectives. Through extensive writing, students examine gendered experiences of participants, spectators, and employees in sports organizations.

course_desc: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global.

course_desc: Cross-cultural theories and perceptions of sexual difference; linkage between biology and cultural constructions of gender; relationship of gender ideology to women’s status.
metadata: Prerequisites: ANTH 152 (or concurrent) or ANTH 301 (or concurrent).; Cross-Listed: ANTH 315; General Education Designation(s): DS

course_desc: Introductory graduate seminar designed to develop common vocabulary and explore the core debates in transnational feminist teaching and research to encourage critical reflection about teaching assumptions, approaches, and techniques in the contemporary college or university environment.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate students only.

course_desc: Introduction to feminist interdisciplinary analysis from global and critical perspectives; relationships between women and men from Asia-Pacific, Hawaiian, and other cultures. Focus on gender, race, class, sexual dynamics, and women’s negotiations with institutional dynamics. Honors students only.
metadata: Prerequisites: departmental approval.; Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DS Honors Program restriction: Yes

course_desc: Students learn how gender and sexuality are constructed online and produce a website to post their analysis and contribute to knowledge production about gender and sexuality in cyberspace.
metadata: Grade Option: A-F only.; General Education Designation(s): DH

metadata: Repeatable: Repeatable one time.; Grade Option: A-F only.; Class Standing Restrictions: Graduate students only.

course_desc: Graduate level introduction to evolution and ecology emphasizing foundational literature, modern models and inference, and major questions in evolution and ecology. Topics include population ecology, community ecology, the genetics of populations, systematics, and speciation.
